title: Former Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi to Unveil New Party
text:
ROME—Italy’s new government suffered its first setback, as the country’s center-left party split in two, complicating life for an already unwieldy governing coalition.

Former Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi has decided to leave the Democratic Party, which formed a government with the antiestablishment 5 Star Movement, to create his own centrist party, according to a person familiar with the matter.

This new party—which Mr. Renzi is expected to unveil on Tuesday—will stay in the governing coalition, the person said. But Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte will now have to manage three parties instead of two, underscoring Italy’s continuing political flux.

The Democrats’ split exemplifies the struggles of Europe’s mainstream political parties, especially on the center-left, to define their identity and rebuild their shrunken voter base in an era of rising antiestablishment sentiment.

The Democrats have been involved in most of Italy’s revolving governments this past decade but have struggled to overcome the country’s economic stagnation. Meanwhile popular discontent with poorly controlled immigration and pressure from the European Union for fiscal retrenchment have fueled a steady rise in voter support for the nationalist right, led by Matteo Salvini’s League party.

Personal rivalries and ambitions have also contributed to the Democrats’ split. Mr. Renzi’s centrist faction lost control of the party leadership earlier this year to the more left-leaning Nicola Zingaretti.

Mr. Renzi showed he is still a key power-broker in Rome in August when he played a leading role in orchestrating the new governing coalition between the Democrats and the 5 Star Movement.

By forming his own party, Mr. Renzi is ensuring that the government will continue to rely on his support, boosting his personal influence.

It remains to be seen whether the new party will make much of an impact with voters, however. Mr. Renzi was briefly a popular prime minister five years ago, but public sentiment turned against him as he struggled to deliver promised overhauls of the country.

The new governing alliance, which took office earlier this month, has little in common apart from a shared desire to avoid snap elections, which opinion polls suggest Mr. Salvini’s League would win.

Mr. Conte, a nonparty premier close to the 5 Star, will now need to manage a more diverse coalition, whose different components may disagree on many matters.

It is unclear how many Democratic Party lawmakers will join Mr. Renzi’s new party.

“While Renzi is unlikely to bring down the government in the shortterm, the immediate consequence of his move is that policymaking will become more complicated, as the government will have to meet the demands of another political party to stay afloat,” said Wolfango Piccoli, co-president of political-risk consulting firm Teneo.
